update.description:
This pull request replaces `boost::shared_ptr` with `std::shared_ptr` in the entirety of the Physics library. `boost::dynamic_pointer_cast`, `boost::static_pointer_cast`, and `boost::const_pointer_cast` have also been replaced with their standard library equivalents.

If you `grep` for any of the above keywords in the physics library, you should get no results.

I also had to touch files in `sensor`, `plugin` and the test suite for compatibility with this change. `ServerFixture::CheckPointer`, a `protected` function, has been changed to take a `std::shared_ptr` instead of a `boost::shared_ptr`. (If the `boost::shared_ptr` function should be deprecated instead of deleted, let me know... I figured this change was OK because it's a. in the test library and b. not a public function.)

Looking to the future, `boost::thread`, `boost::mutex`, and `boost::unordered_set/map` are other candidates for conversion to to their standard library equivalents.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/84/)
update.title: Replaced boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in Physics

content.raw: sadly, because in the physics library basically everything extends from `Base` somewhere down the line, it's hard to do this in smaller parts. I will deprecate the function that I deleted. This PR also needs C++11 enabled in the example plugins to pass tests, so feel free to decline or put on hold until those are enabled

I will deprecate the function that I deleted. This PR also needs C++11 enabled in the example plugins to pass tests, so feel free to decline or put on hold until those are enabled

content.html:
Tick-tock is when one function is marked as deprecated, and a new function is added in its place. Once a full release cycle has passed, the deprecated function is removed.

Example

Tick: Gazebo6

public: void FunctionA() GAZEBO_DEPRECATED(6.0);
public: void FunctionA(int v);

Tock: Gazebo7

public: void FunctionA(int v);

pull_request.title: Replaced boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in Physics

pullrequest.title: Replaced boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in Physics

content.raw: I use it to refer to [deprecation cycle](http://www.scons.org/wiki/DeprecationCycle) in which users receive warnings and have a chance to change their code before the feature is removed.
content.html: I use it to refer to deprecation cycle in which users receive warnings and have a chance to change their code before the feature is removed.

content.raw:
We should tick-tock any public and protected functions that change. 

Doing this in smaller bits would be nice.

Don't have to worry about timing with ROS. They will use gazebo5, most likely until ROS2 comes out.
content.html:
We should tick-tock any public and protected functions that change.

Doing this in smaller bits would be nice.

Don't have to worry about timing with ROS. They will use gazebo5, most likely until ROS2 comes out.

content.raw: ugh, yeah, I did not consider the repercussions of forcing downstream users to migrate to C++11, especially since [ROS Jade](http://www.ros.org/reps/rep-0003.html) will target C++03, though it will compile under a C++11 compiler. I think this is something that needs to happen eventually, but perhaps I should first focus my `sed` powers on replacing structures that do not effect API... `boost::thread` and `boost::mutex` are ideal candidates for replacement
content.html: ugh, yeah, I did not consider the repercussions of forcing downstream users to migrate to C++11, especially since ROS Jade will target C++03, though it will compile under a C++11 compiler. I think this is something that needs to happen eventually, but perhaps I should first focus my sed powers on replacing structures that do not effect API... boost::thread and boost::mutex are ideal candidates for replacement

pull_request.title: Replaced boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in Physics

pullrequest.title: Replaced boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in Physics

content.raw:
This changes our API in a big way. We need to think if there are any ways to mitigate the changes for downstream users (primarily `gazebo_ros_pkgs`). I'm not sure if we can do a tick-tock. As long as they are using the `typedef`'d pointer definitions, they should be fine in terms of variable type definitions, but the `boost::*_pointer_cast` calls will be harder to fix.

It may be something we just have to do all at once and be done with it, but if so, we should be mindful of timing with regard to ROS releases.
content.html:
This changes our API in a big way. We need to think if there are any ways to mitigate the changes for downstream users (primarily gazebo_ros_pkgs). I'm not sure if we can do a tick-tock. As long as they are using the typedef'd pointer definitions, they should be fine in terms of variable type definitions, but the boost::*_pointer_cast calls will be harder to fix.

It may be something we just have to do all at once and be done with it, but if so, we should be mindful of timing with regard to ROS releases.
